evidence.excerpt: Supplier hereby appoints Distributor as the exclusive distributor... Supplier shall not: (a) sell Products directly... (b) appoint other distributors... without Distributor's prior written consent
evidence.reasoning: Correctly identifies non-exclusivity risk and proposes conversion to exclusive with compensation mechanism.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Supplier hereby appoints Distributor as the exclusive distributor... Supplier shall not: (a) sell Products directly... (b) appoint other distributors... without Distributor's prior written consent
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Supplier hereby appoints Distributor as the exclusive distributor... Supplier shall not: (a) sell Products directly... (b) appoint other distributors... without Distributor's prior written consent

gt_evaluations.issue: Non-exclusive appointment with Supplier competition rights

evidence.excerpt: Supplier may modify prices no more than once per calendar year... any price increase shall not exceed five percent (5%) per annum
evidence.reasoning: Adds annual cap at 5%. Less sophisticated than pathfinder (no CPI link, no exit right) but addresses core concern.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Supplier may modify prices no more than once per calendar year... any price increase shall not exceed five percent (5%) per annum
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Supplier may modify prices no more than once per calendar year... any price increase shall not exceed five percent (5%) per annum

gt_evaluations.issue: Unilateral price changes with no cap

evidence.excerpt: subject to adjustment in the event of market downturns, force majeure events, or other circumstances beyond Distributor's reasonable control. Failure to meet minimum purchase requirements... absent good faith renegotiation, shall constitute a material breach
evidence.reasoning: Adds flexibility for external factors and good faith renegotiation requirement.
evidence.judge_reasoning: subject to adjustment in the event of market downturns, force majeure events, or other circumstances beyond Distributor's reasonable control. Failure to meet minimum purchase requirements... absent good faith renegotiation, shall constitute a material breach
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: subject to adjustment in the event of market downturns, force majeure events, or other circumstances beyond Distributor's reasonable control. Failure to meet minimum purchase requirements... absent good faith renegotiation, shall constitute a material breach

gt_evaluations.issue: Mandatory minimum purchase with automatic breach trigger

evidence.excerpt: Neither Party may assign this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Party, except that either Party may assign this Agreement to an affiliate or in connection with a merger, acquisition, or sale
evidence.reasoning: Makes assignment mutual and adds affiliate/M&A exception.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Neither Party may assign this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Party, except that either Party may assign this Agreement to an affiliate or in connection with a merger, acquisition, or sale
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Neither Party may assign this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Party, except that either Party may assign this Agreement to an affiliate or in connection with a merger, acquisition, or sale

evidence.excerpt: this limitation shall not apply to liability arising from Supplier's indemnification obligations, gross negligence, willful misconduct, or breach of confidentiality
evidence.reasoning: Adds carve-outs but doesn't increase cap amount.
evidence.judge_reasoning: this limitation shall not apply to liability arising from Supplier's indemnification obligations, gross negligence, willful misconduct, or breach of confidentiality
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: this limitation shall not apply to liability arising from Supplier's indemnification obligations, gross negligence, willful misconduct, or breach of confidentiality

gt_evaluations.issue: Low liability cap for both parties

evidence.excerpt: Each Party ('Indemnifying Party') shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless... Supplier shall specifically indemnify Distributor for any product liability claims relating to the Products
evidence.reasoning: Comprehensive indemnification clause with product liability coverage.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Each Party ('Indemnifying Party') shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless... Supplier shall specifically indemnify Distributor for any product liability claims relating to the Products
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Each Party ('Indemnifying Party') shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless... Supplier shall specifically indemnify Distributor for any product liability claims relating to the Products

gt_evaluations.issue: No indemnification clause - Distributor exposed to product claims

evidence.excerpt: Title and risk of loss shall pass to Distributor upon actual receipt of the Products at Distributor's designated facility
evidence.reasoning: Changes risk transfer point to actual receipt. Simpler than DDP but addresses transit risk.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Title and risk of loss shall pass to Distributor upon actual receipt of the Products at Distributor's designated facility
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Title and risk of loss shall pass to Distributor upon actual receipt of the Products at Distributor's designated facility

gt_evaluations.issue: FOB shipping terms shift all transit risk to Distributor

evidence.excerpt: interest at the lower of one percent (1%) per month or the maximum rate permitted by applicable law
evidence.reasoning: Reduces rate and adds usury law compliance.
evidence.judge_reasoning: interest at the lower of one percent (1%) per month or the maximum rate permitted by applicable law
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: interest at the lower of one percent (1%) per month or the maximum rate permitted by applicable law

evidence.excerpt: Supplier shall respond within ten (10) business days of receipt, and approval shall be deemed granted if no response is provided
evidence.reasoning: Adds 10-day deemed approval. Longer than pathfinder's 5 days but addresses delay concern.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Supplier shall respond within ten (10) business days of receipt, and approval shall be deemed granted if no response is provided
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Supplier shall respond within ten (10) business days of receipt, and approval shall be deemed granted if no response is provided

gt_evaluations.issue: Marketing approval required for all materials

evidence.excerpt: Distributor may sell remaining inventory for one hundred eighty (180) days; and (d) Supplier shall, at Distributor's option, repurchase any unsold inventory at the original purchase price. Supplier shall provide reasonable transition assistance
evidence.reasoning: Extends sell-off to 180 days, adds buyback and transition assistance.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Distributor may sell remaining inventory for one hundred eighty (180) days; and (d) Supplier shall, at Distributor's option, repurchase any unsold inventory at the original purchase price. Supplier shall provide reasonable transition assistance
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Distributor may sell remaining inventory for one hundred eighty (180) days; and (d) Supplier shall, at Distributor's option, repurchase any unsold inventory at the original purchase price. Supplier shall provide reasonable transition assistance

gt_evaluations.issue: Termination effects lack buyback and transition

evidence.reasoning: CRITICAL MISS: Risk_table 4.1 marked ✅ Favorable with reasoning 'Supplier must accept/reject orders within 5 days, providing certainty to Distributor.' This misses the core issue - Supplier has DISCRETION to reject orders, creating supply uncertainty. The 5-day response time is irrelevant to the no-supply-obligation risk. T1 gate FAIL.

gt_evaluations.issue: Supplier can reject purchase orders - no supply obligation

evidence.reasoning: Risk_table 3.3 marked ✅ Favorable: 'Restricts Distributor from selling outside the Territory, which is standard.' No proposed redline. GT expects concern about growth limitation and passive sales clarification.

evidence.excerpt: this limitation shall not apply to damages arising from Supplier's breach of confidentiality, intellectual property infringement, or willful misconduct
evidence.reasoning: Adds carve-outs for confidentiality, IP, and willful misconduct.
evidence.judge_reasoning: this limitation shall not apply to damages arising from Supplier's breach of confidentiality, intellectual property infringement, or willful misconduct
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: this limitation shall not apply to damages arising from Supplier's breach of confidentiality, intellectual property infringement, or willful misconduct

gt_evaluations.issue: Consequential Damages Exclusion Missing Critical Carve-Outs

additional_issues.notes: The clause gives Supplier sole discretion to approve resellers, which could limit Distributor’s ability to expand its sales network and impact revenue predictability. The approval process and criteria
Products are defined by Exhibit A, which may be amended by mutual written agreement, but the process for amendment is not specified. This could lead to disputes over product scope.
The Territory is defined by Exhibit C, but the process for changes is not addressed. Sudden changes could negatively impact Distributor’s business.
1.5% per month is high (18% annualized); may be excessive or unenforceable in some jurisdictions.
12-month warranty is standard, but “Specifications” are not defined in the contract body (only in Exhibit B, which is not provided).
30-day cure period is standard, but no right to terminate for convenience or for insolvency/bankruptcy.
Standard, but does not specify process for notification, duration, or remedies if event is prolonged.
Not attached; lack of detail could create disputes.
Not attached; lack of detail could create disputes over warranty and performance.
Not attached; lack of detail could create disputes.
Not attached; lack of detail could create disputes.

This amendment ensures that Supplier cannot arbitrarily withhold approval of resellers, which is critical for Distributor’s ability to expand its market and achieve sales targets. By requiring Supplie

Clarifying the amendment process for Exhibit A ensures that Distributor is not subject to sudden or unilateral changes in the scope of Products, which could disrupt business planning and operations. T

This amendment protects Distributor from unilateral or abrupt changes to the Territory, which could undermine investments and market development. Advance notice and mutual agreement are essential to s

Changing to exclusivity strengthens Distributor’s market position and incentivizes investment in marketing and sales. If exclusivity is not possible, alternative protections (such as right of first re

This amendment limits Supplier’s ability to undermine Distributor’s market and provides a mechanism for compensation if Supplier’s actions negatively impact Distributor’s business. It ensures that Dis
This revision ensures that Distributor does not bear the risk of loss or damage during transit, which is outside its control. It aligns risk transfer with actual delivery, reducing exposure to losses

This amendment provides predictability and protection against sudden or excessive price increases, allowing Distributor to plan and manage its business effectively. Limiting the frequency and amount o
This change ensures compliance with local usury laws and avoids excessive penalties for late payment, reducing the risk of unenforceable or punitive charges against Distributor.

This amendment provides flexibility for Distributor in the face of unforeseen market or external events, reducing the risk of automatic breach and termination if minimums cannot be met for reasons out
This amendment prevents undue delays in Distributor’s marketing efforts and ensures that approval cannot be withheld indefinitely, promoting efficient promotion and sales activities.
Referencing a detailed and attached Exhibit B ensures that the warranty is meaningful and enforceable, reducing ambiguity over what constitutes a defect or non-conformance.
This amendment ensures that Distributor retains the benefit of any mandatory statutory warranties and remedies, protecting against overbroad disclaimers that could otherwise leave Distributor without

Carving out exceptions ensures that Distributor is not left without adequate remedies for serious breaches by Supplier, such as IP infringement or willful misconduct, which could have significant busi

This amendment ensures that the liability cap does not apply to the most serious breaches or to indemnification, which could otherwise leave Distributor inadequately protected in the event of signific
Adding rights to terminate for insolvency or for convenience provides Distributor with greater flexibility and protection against being locked into an unfavorable or unworkable arrangement.
Extending the sell-off period and adding a buy-back obligation reduces financial risk for Distributor and ensures an orderly wind-down of business. Transition assistance helps mitigate disruption and
This amendment protects Distributor from being disadvantaged by unfamiliar or unfavorable foreign laws and ensures compliance with mandatory local legal requirements.
This revision addresses the practical and financial burden on Distributor of arbitrating in a distant jurisdiction, making dispute resolution more accessible and equitable.

This amendment ensures parity and flexibility for Distributor, allowing assignment in the context of corporate transactions and preventing Supplier from unilaterally assigning to an unknown third part
Adding notification and termination provisions ensures clarity on the process and provides Distributor with an exit if performance is frustrated for an extended period.

additional_issues.clause: Exhibit A, B, C, D Attachments
